chatGroupDetails.name: Case_118
chatGroupDetails.description: Patient undergoes PTBD and biliary stenting for malignant obstruction. Now presents back with the raised bilirubin levels after clamping of the drain.

question.message:
Displayed is the image from the initial procedure.
What would be the next best step in the management?

data.message: Open the drain and proceed to manage stent occlusion
Grt. Opening/Unclamping the drain should be the first thing todo.
Based on the displayed image, what about the initial placement? Is it appropriate?
Was it distal CBD occlusion
(Not my case): not sure. Still the question would be, is the catheter in an appropriate position.
Yes we have holes above and below the stent
The holes should be covering the whole length of biliary ducts from the entry point to the point beyond the obstruction to ensure adequate drainage from the entire system.
Here even though the stent might be patent the proximal excluded ducts might or can be the cause for elevated bilirubin.

All the ducts proximal to the stent must be one continuous system I presume.. If there are a few holes above the stent it should drain the entire system I guess. Having holes right from the entry point may be impossible for periampullary obstruction. Further if the stent per se was working, then there won''t be jaundice in the first place.. Most likely explanation here is both the stent and the internal drainage of the drain tube is blocked I feel.. Would like to hear others opinion

I agree with the thoughts that it should drain the whole system. However, these do not have normal flow because of the underlying mechanics. As a general rule, we aim to make sure that all parts of the ducts are covered with the drainage. In that context, we try to place the catheter with the last hole draining the periphery aspects of the ducts.

replyTo.message: All the ducts proximal to the stent must be one continuous system I presume.. If there are a few holes above the stent it should drain the entire system I guess. Having holes right from the entry point may be impossible for periampullary obstruction. Further if the stent per se was working, then there won''t be jaundice in the first place.. Most likely explanation here is both the stent and the internal drainage of the drain tube is blocked I feel.. Would like to hear others opinion

data.message: Companies make modified catheters which has extra side holes which can be used in periampullary obstruction cases. If these are not available, we should manually make extra side holes in the cahteter
Dr Varma should give his inputs (Posted the case) about how they managed this case from here.

I have a basic doubt here sir. The holes in the drainage catheter come at predetermined fixed length and in most circumstances we are unable to have holes covering right starting from the entry point. In this case, going by the image of the catheter, if the holes start from the entry point, the pigtail will end up somewhere proximally within the stent which is not ideal for internal drainage
Thats why we need to make extra side holes manually or use a modified catheter which has extra side holes.

replyTo.message: I have a basic doubt here sir. The holes in the drainage catheter come at predetermined fixed length and in most circumstances we are unable to have holes covering right starting from the entry point. In this case, going by the image of the catheter, if the holes start from the entry point, the pigtail will end up somewhere proximally within the stent which is not ideal for internal drainage

data.message: Caution had to be taken while making extra side holes manually, as you might accidentally cut the string
Another thing, I note here is that there is no radioopaque marker along the catheter which determines the location of the last hole

data.clinicalNotes: This is a different case, Post Tx, PTBD. Rising Bilirubin

data.message: As you can see there are undrained segments.

data.clinicalNotes: Catheter was resited in this case

data.message: sorry, sir, I can‚Äôt get my head around this because in case of a communicating obstruction above the confluence, we usually access through one segment and the holes which are above the obstruction, are supposed to drain all of the ducts.. the only thing we make sure is that the holes start beyond the entry point and not proximal to it

I can explain with pictures. As I was getting busier, I googled and this is what I got....AI Overview
When using a biliary catheter for drainage, especially in situations of internal/external drainage, the placement of the holes, or fenestrations, at the periphery (just inside the duct where access is obtained) is crucial for preventing complications and ensuring proper function. 
Here''s why:
Preventing Leakage: If the most peripheral hole is positioned outside the biliary duct, bile can leak along the catheter tract onto the skin, leading to skin irritation and potential infection.
Optimizing Bile Flow: Properly positioned peripheral holes allow bile to drain effectively from the obstructed portion of the biliary system. If the hole is too far in, the bile duct peripheral to the catheter may become obstructed, leading to bile leakage along the course of the catheter.
Facilitating Internal Drainage: Internal/external drains have side holes along the length of the catheter to facilitate bile flow both internally into the small intestine and externally into a drainage bag. The placement of the most peripheral holes just inside the biliary duct is essential for allowing bile to flow through the catheter, across the obstruction, and into the bowel.
Avoiding Vascular Injury: When accessing the biliary system, particularly on the left side, central punctures can increase the risk of injury to the larger hepatic artery and portal vein branches. Targeting more peripheral bile ducts minimizes this risk. 
In summary, ensuring the proper placement of the biliary catheter holes, specifically at the periphery, is critical for achieving optimal drainage, preventing leaks, and minimizing complications like bleeding and infection.
This is new for me.. Great to have a discussion here.. So far we have never had issues with deeper hole position as long as we place them above the obstruction
May be one day....Thanks for the discussion
Would like to know inputs from other operators as well.. Thank you sir
Also, I noticed in India some or most of the biliary catheters have no radioopaque marker or locking system...
Sure. Hope more gets into these discussions. Lets wait..

replyTo.message: Would like to know inputs from other operators as well.. Thank you sir

data.clinicalNotes: We were thinking that the narrowing of stent by the mass was contributing to the outflow block, hence decided to go with a plastic stent.

question.message: Displayed are the intraprocedural images. Comment on the images?

data.message: Wire to periumbilical vein?
Grt. So what will you do now?
while leaving the wire where it is, I would try to advance another wire through the sheath and navigate to main PV

data.clinicalNotes: Before trying the suggestion u mentioned, what about this image?

data.message: Looks like it‚Äôs a large varix. Can consider embolizing it. I‚Äôd secure MPV access before doing anything and even then should think of creating TIPS first and then embolize varix. But this is a controversial topic.
Looks like stricture in the portal vein and main portal vein narrowing (would be more obvious on PACS).
Looks like we needs PVR TIPS here to help with Ascites

data.clinicalNotes: Like you mentioned above, this is what i did. I got alongside with a wire and glidecath

data.message: Thank you! Did you embolize the varices? Or what‚Äôs your take on embolizing primarily?
I didn‚Äôt embolize the varices. Pressure decreased.

chatGroupDetails.name: Case_119
chatGroupDetails.description: An elderly patient presents to ED after a fall. Displayed are the images at the time of presentation.

question.message: What is CT Abdomen/pelvis protocol when the patient presents with trauma?
What is the finding on the displayed images?

data.message: Scan should include plain,15-20 sec delayed arterial phase ,60-70 sec delayed portal venous phase..
It should include from diaphragm D11 till mid thigh
Delayed urographic phase we suspect any bladder injury
Grt. Basically you need 3 phase scan. Non contrast;arterial and delayed. Maybe more delayed in certain cases
What about the findings on the displayed images?
Right gluteal hematoma with blush in venous and delayed phases
Is it arterial and delayed phase?
Do u intervene or conservative management?
ite likely the psudoaneurysm of glueteal artery, with surrounding hematoma, as its appears on arterial phase and persistent on delayed phase. we should intervene as there is high risk of rupture
If this is non-trauma, would you intervene?

if this is because bleeding disorder, coagluation disorder or anticoagulation medication, and if patients hemodynamic is stable, ideal treatment is conservative management (stopping anticoagulant and etc). if patient is hemodynamically unstable, we should intervene in that case also
How would you approach this case?

as there is pseudoaneurysm in right gluteal region, i will start with left CFA puncture, it can be done with right also but i think it will be painful for the patient as well as there is large hematoma on right side. and also from left side it will be easier to perform right CIA angiogram. Radial access also an option.
for artery - 1. CIA run 2. EIA run 3. IIA run.  (likely SGA or IGA)

reaching there with microcatheter, identifying the pseudoA and ideal is sandwich embolization with coil or glue.   if not visible on angio (spasm or anything), USG guided localisation and embo can be tried as an alternative
Too fast.... lets dissect slowly...

replyTo.message: reaching there with microcatheter, identifying the pseudoA and ideal is sandwich embolization with coil or glue.   if not visible on angio (spasm or anything), USG guided localisation and embo can be tried as an alternative

data.message: Anything? Whats next?
is this right common femoral angiogram ?
there is some stasis in this branch but no PSA opacification.
This is Iliac artery angiogram. Whats next?

replyTo.message: is this right common femoral angiogram ?

data.message: we should take Internal iliac angiogram sir as there high chances of gluteal artery injury as per location
i am not able to see IIA and branches in the run
Pseudoaneurysm of the inferior gluteal artery branch (not sure). there are two branches coming off that artery, one branch going distally and normal otherone has this PSA.
we can try to cannulate as distal as possible with microcatheter and embolize using 1. glue 2. coil  3. gelfoam   (glue my 1st choice).  i will use small microcatheter 1.98 Fr probably
